caption: Visiting the Picasso Museum was wonderful. The building has 4 levels that features a number of galleries, sculptures, sketches, and paintings. Be prepared to spend several hours, th coffee shop is off of the main level, a great place to take a minute.

The museum is thee place to see the collection of Picasso Paintings and Sculptures. It has a collection from other famous artists as well. The museum has 3 floors of Art just belonging to Picasso and you get to know about his life so much! A must visit! Totally amazed after visiting.

Picasso Museum, Paris  I loved visiting the Picasso Museum in Paris! Located in the charming Marais district, this museum is in a beautiful historic building and holds over 5,000 artworksâ€”paintings, sculptures, and drawings. Itâ€™s fascinating to see how Picassoâ€™s art evolved through different stages of his life.  Iâ€™ve also been to the Picasso Museum in Barcelona, and both are very different in a great way. The Paris museum showcases his entire career, while Barcelona focuses on his early works. Each collection is unique and complements the other beautifully!  Tips for Your Visit: Book tickets online: It saves time and avoids long lines. Arrive early: Mornings are less crowded. Use the audio guide: It explains the art and Picassoâ€™s life really well. Take your time: Plan for about 2-3 hours to fully enjoy the museum. Check for special exhibits: They often have unique displays. Explore the courtyard: Itâ€™s a peaceful spot for photos. Visit the cafÃ©: A great place for a coffee break. Shop for souvenirs: The gift shop has art books, postcards, and more. This museum is a must-see in Paris, even if youâ€™ve been to the one in Barcelona. Itâ€™s an unforgettable experience!

We explored on 1st Sunday in October 2024; admission was free. Staff was friendly and helpful. The facility was beautiful and rooms lead you through the progression of Picassoâ€™s art until late in life. All types of artistic mediums; most interesting. Hope to compare with Picasso Museum in Barcelona.

Whether or not Picasso is your cup of tea, this museum is well worth a visit. Among the more abtract cubist pieces, there are plenty of other works of interest. I was personally glad to had been there when there was an exhibition of Jackson Pollock paintings also on display. I also recommend the food in the cafe and the outdoor terrace for a bit of Parisien ambience.

I didnâ€™t (and donâ€™t) know much about Picasso when I visited the Picasso museum in MÃ laga last Summer and was impressed by the artwork so I couldnâ€™t avoid going to the Picasso museum in Paris with so many more and different artwork of him. So many paintings and sculptures where you could see his development as an artist. It was really worthwhile visiting. (Unfortunately I can only post the puritan ones otherwise my whole review of this museum will be bounced by the puritan committee of this map)
Well curated and very interesting. We learned the different phases of Picassoâ€™s work, the whole breadth of his stylistic evolution. If you love art, this museum is a must.
Very beautiful museum. Not too crowded. We saw the Jackson Pollock exhibition. Itâ€™s the best to prebook the tickets for the very opening. Itâ€˜s so charming then
I really like this museum, this museum has the most collections of Picasso. I feel itâ€™s a very good museum to visit.

can genuinely say this was one of the coolest and most beautiful museums i have ever been to! the building is amazing and a work of art itself, and the artwork it contains is stunning. there are so many different Picasso pieces and it really gives a look into each stage of his life. tons of drawings, paintings, sculptures, ceramics, as well as his collection of inspirational works that he used. so glad i went while visiting paris!

Must-visit. Well curated flow of artworks. Only thing not so convenient is the audioguide. Audioguide commentary is quite long compared to the other museums Iâ€™ve been in. I kinda hoped it was more concise so I could go around the museum faster.
Great collection showcasing all of Picassso's work over the years. Worth visiting! A nice short walk from other major attractions in the area.
Fantastic Picasso collection plus added bonus of the Jackson Pollock exhibition, all for free in the 1st Sunday of the month. Amazing!
The largest collection of Picasso's works and personal artifacts in the  world. Well worth visiting when in Paris. Buy tickets in advance
Great collection of pieces, the descriptions were written in both french & english. Very clean. Staff were very friendly & helpful. If youâ€™re a fan of arts you must visit!

Visit to the MusÃ©e Picasso in Paris is a must. It houses the largest public collection of Picasso's art, plus pieces from his personal archives including sketchbooks, letters, photographs, and more. Amazing!
Very nice museum, it is not too big but it has a wonderful collection. We saw a Pollock exhibition here as well.

Despite this museum housing some 5,000 works by one of the most well known artists to have lived, I would say it is one of the lesser known museums in Paris. Most people visit the Lourve, Dâ€™Orsay etc, but for the money and quality of the collection I would come here again any day. The museum itself is somewhat difficult to access as despite it being a substantial building the entrance is tucked around a back street without much signage. The collection itself is composed of mostly paintings but also some wonderful sculptures (including superb chandeliers) along with prints and other works on paper. It is very well curated with extensive explanatory texts and full of unexpected delights. It also has good baby changing facilities which are an unfortunate rarity in Paris. Highly recommended
Great Jackson Pollick exhibition, and Picasso.... ðŸ¥° Beside the art pieces, I love the ambient

Must visit museum in Paris! Youâ€™ll never regret itâ€™s worth the price and your attention. Youâ€™ll gain your knowledge in art and how Pablo Picasso as the most renowned viewed artist/ painter whoâ€™s actually not only painter but he has so much other artworks that you canâ€™t really tell before.

Your average museum of not-average painter! Got a small nice cafe on the terrace of the second floor where you can get a break before exploring two more storeys. Audio guide in English, Spanish, French, Italian and few more languages available

Great collection of his works and some types Iâ€™ve never seen even after years of living in DC and NYC.    Best of all, the cafe here has a gorgeous terrace overlooking the courtyard as a rest.   The most recent renovation leaves a lot to be desired and isnâ€™t sensitive like we see at Musee de la Chasse.  Definitely a must  see.

What a beautiful collection of art. This is the perfect size of museum for most visitors. The collection of Picasso's is magnificent. The collection was re-installed with lots of color and graphics added to the rooms. This is not a white-wall presentation. There are colors, stripes, and patterns that help put the art in context and its easier to consume for many viewers. Small roof-top cafe is perfect for a break.
Itâ€™s a beautiful building, spacious airy rooms. The way the works arranged is also an art. The caffe could have a  better food choice.

I love Picasso, but I was ultimately disappointed. On arrival, the security at the gate sent me back out of the gate because of my assistance dog. I understand the need to verify, but I hoped I would be treated with a little respect and invited to wait inside the courtyard versus on the narrow pavement outside. The museum, what I could experience, was amazing. I was unable to visit 1 and a half floors because of out of service lifts. It is difficult to experience life in a wheelchair and even harder when places do not keep accessible equipment serviced. What I saw was amazing.

(14â‚¬/ Person) This museum is a mixed exhibit of Picassoâ€™s work and conceptual artist, Sophie Calleâ€™s work in celebration of Pablo Picassoâ€™s 50th death anniversary spread out in this 4 floor gallery. I very much enjoyed Picassoâ€™s bit-  A note to all, this exhibit will be only until March 2024!  Oh! And the souvenir shop is adorable as well!

The museum is free for U26 EU resident and the checkin is also really quick. The exhibition were good and it's also near many other private galleries that you can add to your visit list too.  But I gave a 4 because something happened (and I don't know why) when I was sitting downstair the security were getting everyone to go up to the exit without letting everyone going back to visit the exhibition (since there's only 1 way out from what I know).  So I kind of glad I got in for free otherwise I haven't seen anything yet and have to get out

Itâ€™s been decades since Iâ€™ve visited this museum and Iâ€™m so glad I did.  Set in an impressive mansion the Picasso / Paul Smith exhibition did not fail to impress.  Iconic masterpieces and less known works set against stunning decor.  The building is an architectural marvel that combines modernity with history. Donâ€™t miss it
Itâ€™s an absolute gem. Picassoâ€™s archives and collections are displayed in a perfect timeline manner as you move from room to room with a lot of context explanations on the walls.
Great musee with lots of information aswell as paintings to see, glad we booked in advance online then got paper ticket from the reception desk. There is a nice little terrace cafe with basic snacks.

Itâ€™s probably best to navigate here using Gmaps if itâ€™s your first time going, there arenâ€™t any big signs to let you know that youâ€™re actually at the museum already. You get in free if you have a Cultivist membership, just get a map at the lobby and then head downstairs where Picassoâ€™s works are located. The lady didnâ€™t know what to scan, but a supervisor ended up helping us get in. For art casuals, itâ€™s okay, lots of interesting pieces to look at and read about, you can probably spend an hour here. Heading up to the upper floors where Sophie Calleâ€™s works are at, there are a lot of rooms and pieces to explore, probably worth half a day to explore.

Skip it. Not worth the time. There are only about 30 of the artist's works here, and many of those are studies, not the final product. The rest of the space is dedicated to contemporary artists that are clearly looking for the foot traffic that the Picasso museum generates in order to promote their own work. (Meh)  You're better off spending more time at the Louvre or MusÃ©e d'Orsay while in Paris. Go see Picasso's work at other museums around the world. That's where the good stuff is.

The museum located in a calm place and contains more than 3000 pieces of Picasso works. You can find painting, sculpture, drawing, ceramic art, even poetry. All those arts was given by his family after his death to France especially because Pablo lives there the whole life.  For those who likes art they will love it.  PS: Finally I met la chÃ©vre de monsieur Seguin hhhh.

The private palace where the museum is located is very beautiful, as is the terrace on which you can eat or drink coffee. But I think I forgot to visit some corners of the museum because it is very complicated to follow, but I wanted to and did not see enough of Picassoâ€™s works, as on display are a few paintings by Picasso and the rest are works of art by other artists. In any case, the museum is dedicated to Picasso, and most of the exhibits are not by Picasso

What a stunning gallery this is. I loved seeing all the variety of Picasso's works. This collection gave me a fantastic overall view of his life work. It was not crowded, so I could enjoy each piece of work in detail. Definitely well worth a visit!

Excellent. An overload of Picasso but I loved it. Discovered so much I never knew about his work. Also had a Jackson Pollock exhibition which was also extremely informative. I thoroughly recommend it. Do go. Worth every penny.

What an incredible discovery in Paris. The Picasso museum is located in a beautiful neighborhood in the city. You'll find the entrance at a big square after entering through a gate. The building itself consists of different floors. At the moment of visiting, they had 2 temporary exhibitions by other artists, both impressive and with a link to the work of Picasso. The Picasso collection itself starts with his younger days and goes on through different stages in his life. This museum does a really good job in making the rooms fit exactly with what you see in the painting. For example, his blue period and the time he used a lot of colored stripes are both combined combined with rooms in the same colors and style. In this way, you really see the connection between his work. The 5 floors aren't really big, which makes it a great museum to visit for a maximum of 1,5 hours. All together, it's a really worth visit if you're interested in the work of Spanish painter Picasso. 4.8/5.0
I absolutely loved this museum. It had such a wide collection of Picasso's works, that is something you won't find anywhere else. Even the building was beautiful. Loved it.
